tickets.description:
It would be nice if it would be possible to measure 
over a proxy, which needs an authentication.

Or is there already a way?

Lars

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865

No way I'm aware of :-\) \(Same problem for ordinary HTTP.\)
Patches are welcome, I don't have such a proxy to test.

RFC 2068,  sections 14.33 and 14.34.

posts.subject: #1 proxy authentication

tickets.description:
Hello,
Would it be possible to add a command option for
turing the ecn bits on and off? Thanks...

posts.text:
Logged In: NO 

Can't you just do
echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/tcp\_ecn \# on
and
echo 0 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/tcp\_ecn \# off
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #2 Add ECN option

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865

I'm not aware of a way to turn ECN \(RFC 3168,
http://www.icir.org/floyd/ecn.html\) on from the program
\(even a non-portable one\), specially on a per-connection basis.

The Linux-specific technique posted by nobody on 2004-08-12
seems the right solution.
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #2 Add ECN option

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> bortz
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #2 Add ECN option

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865

Suggested by Pierre Beyssac :

netinet/ip.h on FreeBSD contains:

/\* ECN bits proposed by Sally Floyd \*/
\#define IPTOS\_CE                0x01    /\* congestion
experienced \*/
\#define IPTOS\_ECT               0x02    /\* ECN-capable
transport \*/

We could try to setsockopt with these values and see what
happens.

On systems without IPTOS\_CE \(Linux\), we could detect this
with autoconf or simply:

\#ifndef IPTOS\_CE
\#define IPTOS\_ECT               0x02    /\* ECN-capable
transport \*/
\#endif

This is something to test.
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #2 Add ECN option

tickets.description:
Is it possible to show datetime on every request 
echoping?
For example

%  echoping -n 2 -h / mywww
16-08-2005 14:32:34 Elapsed time: 0.686792 seconds
16-08-2005 14:32:35 Elapsed time: 0.686792 seconds

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: NO

Not currently, but I do note it as a feature request.
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #4 Timestamp

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> bortz
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #4 Timestamp

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: NO

But I am not convinced: 

1\) It raises l10n issues which echoping happily avoided until now

2\) It may be done outside of echoping, specially if you do not use -n
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #4 Timestamp

tickets.description:
I've been very pleased using echoping with smokeping to
monitor network resources.  I would also like to be
able to monitor the response of the campus wide DHCP
server and was hoping echoping could accomodate that
some how along with all the other tests it does.  DHCP
server testing seems to be an undertested element of
the network that could cause major headaches.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: NO

This would certainly be an interesting feature.

First thing to test: how to send a DHCP request which will \*not\* hoard an IP address? If we want to monitor periodically, we must not exhaust the address pool. May be a DHCPREQUEST immediately followed by a DHCPRELEASE?
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #8 DHCP

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: NO

Read RFC 2131 \(IPv4\) and 3315 \(for IPv6\)
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #8 DHCP

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> bortz
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #8 DHCP

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: NO

Other possible solutions to avoid "hoarding" by echoping:

\* requesting a lease of 0 \(or, if illegal, of one second\),

\* using only DHCPINFORM instead of DHCPREQUEST \(but it may not reflect the actual working of the server\)
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #8 DHCP

tickets.description:
IWBNI we could display the kurtosis of the distribution \(a measure of its "peakedness"\).

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurtosis
http://www.statsoft.com/textbook/glosi.html\#Kurtosis \(for the formula\)

Implementations in C welcome :-\)

It would be useful for driving
echoping from a GUI application, for instance, where immediate flushing is necessary. Code does exist but
untested and probably broken.

Some plugins \(for instance for RTP\) may like to have UDP-Lite \(RFC 3828\) support.

Read \(in French\) http://www.bortzmeyer.org/3828.html

Starting with 2.6.20, Linux kernel has UDP-Lite.

Following a suggestion from Tobias Oetiker : the remaining thing is
parallel operation ... analog to fping, this would be great as it
would increasse the performance of eechoping greatly ... This would
require changing echoping and creating a loop around select\(\).

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: YES

It is a big and long-term change. For an ambitious student :-\) echoping Summer of Code ?
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #14 Parallel operation

posts.text: - **assigned_to**: nobody --> bortz
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #14 Parallel operation

tickets.description:
IWBN to support SCTP \(RFC 3286\)\)

Read \(in French\) http://www.bortzmeyer.org/3286.html

Linux implementation : http://lksctp.sourceforge.net/
FreeBSD implementation : http://lists.freebsd.org/pipermail/freebsd-current/2006-November/067218.html

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: YES

r414 added an experimental SCTP support \(tested only on a recent Linux\)
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #15 SCTP support

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: YES

The detection of SCTP by checking IPPROTO\_SCTP is not ideal because old Unix \(here a Debian "sarge"\) have the variable but the kernel may not support it:

eve:echoping/trunk/SRC % grep SCTP config.h
\#define HAVE\_SCTP 
eve:echoping/trunk/SRC % ./echoping -v -T localhost

This is ./echoping, version 6.1-BETA.

Can't open socket \(Socket type not supported\)
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #15 SCTP support

posts.text:
A RFC describing the standard API for SCTP has just been published: RFC 6458.

Apparently, as of today, no implementation of SCTP follows it.
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #15 SCTP support

tickets.summary: More TCP_INFO from the TCP stack
tickets.description:
echoping 6 will display the RTT measured by TCP and obtained from TCP\_INFO but IWBN to display more information.

http://linuxgazette.net/136/pfeiffer.html

It seems that the tcpinfo struct is not documented, except by the sources of the Linux  kernel? For instance, what is the metric behind "reordering"?

In order to move the SMTP code outside of the core, we need a SMTP plugin.

Among other things, it must allow to:

\* test other TCP ports, for instance SUbmission port 587 \(see \#1275764\)

\* set the hostname in EHLO \(see \#1512776\)

\* \(may be\) sen a complete email message

\* \(may be\) use TLS via STARTTLS

There is currently \*no\* plugin interface where the TCP connection and shutdown are done by echoping. We have:

\* the raw interface, where the plugin receives a host name and does everything \(including the host name resolution\)

\* the cooked interface, where the plugin receives a struct addrinfo, and the host name resolution is done by echoping but connect\(\) is still done by the plugin, leading to duplication of code and difficulty to use options like TCP\_INFO

We need a third interface, "well-done", where the plugin receives a socket file descriptor, where the connection has already been done.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: YES

Or may be:

\* raw
\* medium \(instead of just "cooked"\)
\* well done

This leaves "rare" :-\)
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #18 A new plugin interface, "well-done"

posts.text: UvW5SN  <a href="http://aogjhrwlqkmr.com/">aogjhrwlqkmr</a>, \[url=http://uymjctjrojms.com/\]uymjctjrojms\[/url\], \[link=http://hcftemdxsthi.com/\]hcftemdxsthi\[/link\], http://desfqrsmjjzz.com/
posts.author: nobody
posts.subject: #18 A new plugin interface, "well-done"

tickets.description:
In order to move any many protocols as possible to plugins \(and then to unbloat echoping.c\), the first victim will be discard. The roadmap is:

\* write a discard plugin,
\* delete the discard code,
\* call the plugin when the -d option is given
IWBN to move the huge HTTP code outside of echoping.c completely. Long-term task, it is complicated code.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=25865
Originator: YES

Among the needed features in the new plugin, HTTP authentication.
posts.author: bortz
posts.subject: #20 A HTTP plugin

tickets.description:
The current DNS plugin uses res\_query to send the actual query. It has two bad consequences:

\* retrying is done by res\_query, which partially defeats echoping. For instance, the timeout is res\_query's, not echoping's \(hence the common 5 s delay, which is the retrying time of res\_query\)

\* IPv6 support is impossible since there is apparently no standard way of changing the default name server for an IPv6 address \(the current code tries to use res\_ext which is non-standard and, anyway, the code is broken\)

A better solution would be to use the resolver library only to create \(res\_mkquery\) and parse the packet but to send it myself with send\(\) \(or may be res\_send\) and recv\(\).

posts.text: I wonder if there is any progress on this one? Because I would be very much interested in watching IPv6 DNS servers with echoping.
posts.author: traxo
posts.subject: #21 A new DNS plugin?
